description: Large systems versus small programs. Problems of scale. Software life-cycle: design phase, implementation phase, testing, maintenance. Software re-use. Tools/Toolkits/Libraries. Programming as a group activity. Support tools, e.g., SCCS and RCS. Standards. Software readability and structure. Reading code. Style sheets. Software Testing: role in process, test cases, testers. Documentation. Embedded documentation and external documentation.
name: SOFTWARE DESIGN/ENGINEER

values.comments: The various topics covered in this course include: Large systems versus small programs. Problems of scale. Software life-cycle: design phase, implementation phase, testing, maintenance. Software re-use. Tools/Toolkits/Libraries. Programming as a group activity. Support tools, e.g., SCCS and RCS. Standards. Software readability and structure. Reading code. Style sheets. Software Testing: role in process, test cases, testers. Documentation. Embedded documentation and external documentation.  Most students enjoyed the course. Some students felt that “more guest lecturers would have been helpful.” Others said that the “large project was difficult to fit into an undergraduate’s schedule.” Overall, the students felt that they learned “great concepts” during the course, and that it was a good experience.   Students praised Professor Smith for his teaching and course organization. Students also said that he was “able to tell good jokes.” His style was also “calm and slow-paced,” which “reduced the stress” for some students.   Overall, students felt that the “workload was manageable.” It was considered to be a “good course to add to an undergraduate curriculum.” This course was suggested for majors only.
